messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Just recieved
messages.msgSnippet: HI mate, thanks for the book update, yes I spotted Gordon, I think he is what we call here in OZ, a camera pig LOL. Can t keep his face out of the
messages.messageBody:
HI mate, thanks for the book update, yes I spotted Gordon, I think he is
what we call here in OZ, a camera pig LOL. Can't keep his face out of
the press.......... Great to see Alan Harvey, Bob Haynes with their
smiles in the pics as well, Sorry, I am unsure of Julie Duncan, probably
a cardinal sin but........

Looking forward very much to the book.

Rich

> the text is being proof read now.

> Yagyu tsuba. He's in the special "dai" gloves. That's Alan Harvie to
> Gordon's left and Julie Duncan in the background.
>
> Jim
>
>
>
> my copy of this months NCJSC mag and was salivating over the Yagyu
> collection, as well as the description of all of the Kodogu and
> Koshirae
> in the back but ohhhhh were are all the pictures LOL.
>
> So, does anyone have a rough idea when the NBTHK A will be releasing
> the
> book ?????
>
> cheers all
>
> Rich
>
> p.s. Both Gordon and Jim look very dappa in their mug shots :-) Nice to
> finally put a face to all the emails Jim.
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Just recieved
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The plan is to have the book of the JuBi and Yagyu display ready in time for the Tampa show in February.  The photography is finished and the text is
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The plan is to have the book of the JuBi and Yagyu display ready in time for the Tampa show in February. The photography is finished and the text is being proof read now.

The paparazzi were out in force at the SF show. Note that Gordon also makes an uncredited appearance in the upper right photo above the Yagyu tsuba. He's in the special "dai" gloves. That's Alan Harvie to Gordon's left and Julie Duncan in the background.

Jim



my copy of this months NCJSC mag and was salivating over the Yagyu
collection, as well as the description of all of the Kodogu and Koshirae
in the back but ohhhhh were are all the pictures LOL.

So, does anyone have a rough idea when the NBTHK A will be releasing the
book ?????

cheers all

Rich

p.s. Both Gordon and Jim look very dappa in their mug shots :-) Nice to
finally put a face to all the emails Jim.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Just recieved
messages.msgSnippet: For Canadians, there is also the Toronto Token Kai sword study group that is run through the Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre. Please see:
messages.messageBody:
For Canadians, there is also the Toronto Token Kai sword study group that is run through the Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre. Please see: http://www.jccc.on.ca/classact/indexactivities.shtml
____________________________________________
Doug Blain, Manager, Information Technology Security
Computing & Communications Services,
University of Guelph
Phone: (519) 824-4120 ext. 56475
Fax: (519) 767-1620

----- Original Message -----
From: David Zincavage
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, September 15, 2005 3:52 PM

http://www.japaneseswordsocietyofcanada.org/

messages.subject: NCJSC membership
messages.msgSnippet: Does anyone know if there is a way to join the NCJSC using Paypal as payment? Would like to join, but can only use PP for various reasons. Looks very
messages.messageBody:
Does anyone know if there is a way to join the NCJSC using Paypal as
payment? Would like to join, but can only use PP for various reasons.
Looks very worthwhile to join, especially with the lack of resources
here in South Africa.

Brian

messages.msgSnippet: David; The NCJSC publishes its news letter monthly.  It is a very good and informative journal.  It is free to all members of the NCJSC.  I think membership is
messages.messageBody:
David;

The NCJSC publishes its news letter monthly. It is a very good and informative journal. It is free to all members of the NCJSC. I think membership is $30. a year.

John

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Just recieved
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich, Yeah, the cat is out of the bag mug shot wise. The koshirae is next to my silly self and you can pick out most of the tsuba. The menuki at the bottom
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich,

Yeah, the cat is out of the bag mug shot wise. The koshirae is next to
my silly self and you can pick out most of the tsuba. The menuki at the
bottom left are Ko-Kinko, late Muromachi and Goto Joshin, late
Muromachi. The colection of fittings, bottom right are all Ko-Kinko,
late Muromachi and Momoyama except the two kogai on the right and the
two kozuka below them. These are Goto Sojo, Ko-Goto, Goto Joshin and
Ko-Goto. You can see that everyone was having a great time.

Gordon

messages.messageBody:
my copy of this months NCJSC mag and was salivating over the Yagyu
collection, as well as the description of all of the Kodogu and Koshirae
in the back but ohhhhh were are all the pictures LOL.

So, does anyone have a rough idea when the NBTHK A will be releasing the
book ?????

cheers all

Rich

p.s. Both Gordon and Jim look very dappa in their mug shots :-) Nice to
finally put a face to all the emails Jim.

from the photos. You should be able to find published examples for
comparison.

identification

> At the centre are depicted two horses in high relief, one of
gold and
> the other of shakudo. The reverse is of polished shakudo and,
> unfortunately, the mei is too badly rubbed to be easily
identified.
> It consists of five characters, the fourth of which may
be 'taka' and
> the fifth probably a kao. The first two kangi are NOT Yanagawa!

> I fear that the very unsatisfactory photograph is the best

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kodzuka identification ...
messages.msgSnippet: John, The signature is Goto Mitsutaka (kao).  That would be Enjo, the 13th mainline Goto, 1721-1784. I m not very confident about the mei, but I don t want to
messages.messageBody:
John,
The signature is Goto Mitsutaka (kao). That would be Enjo, the 13th mainline Goto, 1721-1784.

I'm not very confident about the mei, but I don't want to judge from the photos. You should be able to find published examples for comparison.

Regards,
Jim



Can any kind and knowledgeable member assist me in the identification
of the maker of the kodzuka illustrated in my photo album JPL?

The obverse is horizontal shakudo nanako, surrounded by a raised rim.
At the centre are depicted two horses in high relief, one of gold and
the other of shakudo. The reverse is of polished shakudo and,
unfortunately, the mei is too badly rubbed to be easily identified.
It consists of five characters, the fourth of which may be 'taka' and
the fifth probably a kao. The first two kangi are NOT Yanagawa!

I fear that the very unsatisfactory photograph is the best possible,
considering the state of the mei but, given a suggested maker, I may
be able to marry that name to what remainss of the kangi.

With thanks in anticipation, John L.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

ye all,
stilling smarting over the loss of that wabi/sabi black raku bowl by a
person who shall remain nameless, I took a quick look see at the
photo...............
it's a goto school, may be the 15th master ? The mei looks very familiar (
as I have a few koz with that type of mei ).
Gordon, you really shouldn't be drinking red for breakfast.............
can't see, then can't find your glasses leading to more trouble looking........
it's a vicious circle.


milt

messages.subject: Kodzuka identification ...
messages.msgSnippet: Can any kind and knowledgeable member assist me in the identification of the maker of the kodzuka illustrated in my photo album JPL? The obverse is horizontal
messages.messageBody:
Can any kind and knowledgeable member assist me in the identification
of the maker of the kodzuka illustrated in my photo album JPL?

The obverse is horizontal shakudo nanako, surrounded by a raised rim.
At the centre are depicted two horses in high relief, one of gold and
the other of shakudo. The reverse is of polished shakudo and,
unfortunately, the mei is too badly rubbed to be easily identified.
It consists of five characters, the fourth of which may be 'taka' and
the fifth probably a kao. The first two kangi are NOT Yanagawa!

I fear that the very unsatisfactory photograph is the best possible,
considering the state of the mei but, given a suggested maker, I may
be able to marry that name to what remainss of the kangi.

With thanks in anticipation, John L.
